post.title: The Ultimate Guide to Cinque Terre's Best Beaches
post.subtitle: From the sandy shores of Monterosso to the hidden rocky coves of Riomaggiore, we explore the most pristine swimming spots in the Italian Riviera.
post.author: Giulia Rossi
post.authorBio: Born and raised in Riomaggiore, Giulia has swum in every cove along this coastline. She knows which rocks are best for jumping and where to find shade at noon.

content.intro: The Cinque Terre is not known for its beaches in the traditional sense. There are no long stretches of white sand, no palm-lined boardwalks. Instead, you'll find rocky coves carved by the sea, pebble beaches tucked beneath towering cliffs, and swimming spots that require a bit of effort to reach.

sections.title: What to Expect
sections.text: Most beaches here are rocky or pebbly. Water shoes are essential, not optional. The water is crystalline—some of the clearest in the Mediterranean—but the entry can be challenging. The best swimming is often from the flat rocks at the edge of the sea, not from a gentle slope of sand.

sections.title: Monterosso: The Only True Sandy Beach
sections.text: Monterosso is the exception. In the new town (Fegina), you'll find a long stretch of sand with beach clubs offering umbrellas and loungers. It's the most accessible swimming in the Cinque Terre and the best choice for families with young children.

sections.title: Riomaggiore Harbor: The Local Favorite
sections.text: The harbor of Riomaggiore isn't a beach—it's a concrete boat ramp and a collection of flat rocks. But this is where the locals swim. The water is deep, clear, and cold. You can jump from the rocks and watch the fishing boats come and go.

sections.title: Guvano Beach: The Hidden Secret
sections.text: Between Corniglia and Vernazza lies Guvano, a naturist beach accessible only by a long, abandoned railway tunnel. It's not for everyone, but for those seeking solitude and a wild swimming experience, it's unmatched.

quote.text: The best swimming in the Cinque Terre isn't about the destination—it's about the moment. The coldness of the water after a hot climb. The way the cliffs look from sea level. The feeling of the Mediterranean on your skin.
quote.author: Giulia Rossi
